children.text: The idea is to iterate over starting indices i, and then for each i, we extend j as far as possible such that the subarray a[i:j] is Decinc. Then the number of subarrays starting at i is (j-i). Then we add that to ans. The code has a while loop that starts at j = i, and then we have two variables: u (for the last element of the increasing sequence) and d (for the last element of the decreasing sequence). Initially, u=0 (since we haven't taken any for increasing) and d = n+1 (a big number for decreasing).
children.label: high_level_plan

The algorithm: 
  We try to extend j until we break the condition for being Decinc.

        if u < a[j] < d: # if can insert to both

        elif u < a[j]: # if only can insert to increasing subsequence
            u = a[j]
        elif d > a[j]: # if only can insert to decreasing subsequence
            d = a[j]
        else:

The condition: if the current element a[j] can be added to both sequences, then we choose based on the next element.

By assigning the current element to the increasing sequence when the next element is larger, we leave the decreasing sequence unchanged and the increasing sequence updated to a[j] (which is the largest so far). Then the next element (a[j+1]) must be greater than u (which is now a[j]) to be added to the increasing sequence? But if a[j+1] is greater than a[j], then it is greater than u. 

Similarly, if we assign to the decreasing sequence when the next element is smaller, then the decreasing sequence becomes a[j] (the smallest so far) and then the next element must be less than d (which is now a[j]) to be added to the decreasing sequence? But if a[j+1] is less than a[j], then it is less than d. But what if we have a choice and the next element is not increasing or decreasing?
